The Blackwell Legacy is a short and sweet point-and-click adventure game wherein you help wandering spirits pass on to the afterlife by helping them realise their current situation. It features puzzles that require decent comprehension, a good amount of research, and involvement with all participating characters. After playing it for 2 hours, here's what I think..

- the game makes good use of notes; they really look for the ability to put two and two together
- short and sweet (Only one case is covered but it is quote memorable due to the nature of all the different characters the developer managed to fit in.)

Con:

- quite a few parts of the game did not require much (if any) object interaction

___________

I recommend this game to anyone who is looking to start playing point-and-click adventure games. It's a great starting point. It's well-made and short (not tedious) so it will ease you into the genre. The story itself is solid if you understand that this game is an introduction to the series (The Blackwell Series of games).

reviewText:
(For reference, the correct play order is Legacy - Unbound - Convergence - Deception - Epiphany. The series pretty much plays like 5 chapters of a single game, so this review is the same for each.)

You play Rosa Blackwell, who much to her annoyance has inherited the family spirit guide- Joey Mallone, a 1930's gangster type who absolutely insists she spends her evenings resolving supernatural oddities by calming the ghosts causing them and helping them move on to the next world. Of course, only Rosa can see and talk to these ghosts, so traipsing around New York apparently talking to herself is the order of the day.

Right off the bat, Blackwell is sure to evoke nostalgia in those of us who played adventure games back in the day. Remove the voice acting and you could convince me these were hidden Amiga gems that were recently unearthed. The pixel art changes in style between each game but is always crisp, clear, and remarkably detailed- some animations are a little choppy but that's kinda nostalgic too.

The games are easily comparable to the Phoenix Wright titles, and I'd say anyone who enjoyed those will have a good time here. The focus is much more on the story than the puzzles, which usually involve gathering information from the right places and using it to help the ghosts realise their time in the mortal world is over. It rarely falls into the adventure game traps of obtuse puzzles that make no real sense, and the times it does are almost entirely in the first game- in-game commentary from the developer notes that he's well aware of these early stumbles and actively avoided them later.

Probably the point that will discourage those who watched the trailer is the voice acting, which early on is admittedly amateur and clearly done on home hardware rather than in a studio. Please, PLEASE do not let that turn you off the series. If it's a dealbreaker you can turn voice acting off completely in each game, and after the first two games it gets markedly better. I was unsure on Abe Goldfarb's performance as Joey to begin with, but by the end of the series I couldn't imagine anyone else in the role. Just.... Just weather the storm and it'll pay off later, trust me.

All told you're looking at 15-20 hours for the five games (though that depends a lot on how good you are with solving the mysteries) and achievement hunters will play through each one twice, though the second time through is a lot quicker. I became very attached to Rosa and Joey in my time with them and I'll miss them now their adventure is over.

reviewText:
The Blackwell Legacy is the first game in the Blackwell series (the others being Blackwell Unbound, Blackwell Convergence and Blackwell Deception in order of release, with a fifth and final game coming soon).

Modled on old school point and click adventure games, this takes both the good and the bad from the genre. While the story and the characters (and when I say characters I mean the protaganists) are well developed and some of the puzzles are well thought out, there's a lot of backtracking and a few puzzles that just don't work and the game refuses to help assist you, with no hints or advice.

The story involes Rosa a young girl in New York whose only relative, her Aunt, recently passed away having spent most of Rosa's life in a mental ward. Whilst investigating a local suicide for a newspaper article Rosa encounters the ghost of Joey Mallone who explains that like her Aunt she is a medium and must help lost sprirts move on.

There's more to the story in the game, and it also develops further over the sequals, so to say anymore would be spoling it. The game is fully voice acted and Rosa and Joey's actors put in excelent performances, though the rest of the characters vary from poor to good. The graphics are relaible, with charcter models and backdrops looking a lot like older P&C adventures, but still seeming fairly modern.

I got stuck once or twice at some of the previously mentioned poor puzzles (THE F&%*ING DOG LEAD) but there are plenty of guides online to help you out. The game is quite short and will proably take aywhere between 2-4 hours to complete first time round, however there are 8 achivements to earn, only 3 of which you get for just playing the game to completeion as standard, and a commentary mode by the creator (wherein he talks about the creation of the game the difficulties and what he learnt from it) which adds extra playtime.

Quick Sumarry:
+ Intresting Story and Charcters
+ Some clever puzzles
+ Good voice acting for the main protagainsts
+ Great music and decent graphics
- Some really frustrating puzzles
- Too much bactracking
- Alot is just set up for the sequals.

Score 7/10

reviewText:
The Blackwell Legacy was my first foray into anything put out by Wadjet Eye Games. To put it succinctly, I was not disappointed. This game is proof the point-and-click adventure genre is in the midst of a resurgance and not relying on the old stalwarts to do so.

You're thrown into things fairly rapidly in The Blackwell Legacy, but not so much that it feels too rushed. As Rosangela Blackwell, a down on her luck journalist scraping by in New York City, you're suddenly greeted by the spectre of Joey, a ghostly fellow who seems a few decades out of place. As the game progresses, you learn why Joey's decided to hang out with you, that you might be connected to him somehow, and what you and Joey are meant to do in the world. As it stands, New York City has a lot more going on behind the scenes than anyone expected.

I'm keeping things especially vague due to potential spoilers, but the story in The Blackwell Legacy is very solid. A tightly knit tale that lays out a spread of characters bound to return in future Blackwell titles, Legacy still manages to stand well on its own, proving more than just a mere set-up for the series. As for gameplay, it's fairly standard point-and-click fare, with the added twist of an online (in-game) search engine thrown in to both fit the setting and avoid more ridiculous combinations of exploration and item scrounging. It's a bit frustrating that you need to return to Rosa's apartment every time you need to conduct a search, but it's still handy having it available.

One of the biggest delights (and tips) going into things, at least for me, is how Joey and Rosa both have distinct abilities and uses for the various situations that come up. While you primarily control Rosa this time around, I highly recommend keeping tabs on Joey's wanderings around each scene, as these frequently tip you off as to things you need him to do to progress. That, and sometimes, it's just funny.

The voice acting is extremely on point, as are the visuals representing those voices and the writing behind them. The Blackwell games changed artistic hands as each follow-up was released, but the core style is always consistent and the entire thing feels like variations on a theme rather than hiring whoever was available.

Absolutely take The Blackwell Legacy for a spin, and save yourself a few bucks by getting the whole series bundle.

(Note: I'm aware my profile shows no achievements for this game despite having 14 hours on record. I'm not sure if I played it on another platform before it came to Steam, or played it on Steam prior to it getting achievements, or let it run at some point to collect the cards, but I submit this video as proof I have played the game through. It's a good concept. A loner girl solves ghost mysteries with the help of a smartly dressed family heirloom ghost and then sucks ghosts into an afterlife gateway in her brain. All wrapped up in a tasty point-and-click adventure game package! Hell, put like that, it's a GREAT concept.

I don't know what happened between concept and reality, but it should have looked both ways before crossing the street.

The Blackwell Legacy manages to spur my advances at every turn. I want to love it for its concept, I want to love it for what it aspires to be. But it's got so many issues it's dealing with, and it knows I don't find it pretty, and it doesn't think anybody could love it, so although it permits me a date, the date ends early with both of us going home alone, crying.

I hope that metaphor made sense to someone, because I'm not proofreading it.

At the very outset, red flags go up. In the opening cutscene, our heroine offers some clunky dialogue to an urnful of ashes, and we're shortly thereafter given control in front of a dull building with nothing to meaningfully interact with outside of a frustrating 20-something barring us access to our own apartment because he doesn't recognize us. It's a bad note to start on. Already I want to punch something and I've only been playing for two minutes (and as I don't recall this person ever being set on fire, I can safely say that the situation doesn't end satisyingly enough).

Soon after, you encounter another hurdle. Puzzles in The Blackwell Legacy don't work like those of a traditional point-and-click. Which is fine; innovation is commendable! But it doesn't really know what to replace them with. Solving problems usually consists of one of two things: clicking dialogue subjects at people and on each other in order to eek out a tiny bit more plot to go on, or fiddling with the world around you. Here, at the beginning of the game, you do the latter, and it's entirely too unintuitive for being the first puzzle of the game (or any puzzle of the game). And it's here, also, that you discover another major issue: your character kind of sucks.

Rosangela, the protagonist, is herself one of the biggest obstacles in the game. I understand the point of watching a character get over their personal problems. But it almost seems like her personal problems are simply an excuse for having Rosangela refuse to do most of the things you want her to. I don't think I've ever had a character in my control say the word no" so much in a single game

reviewText:
Rosa Blackwell's life isn't going so well. She's become an antisocial shut-in, her work as an amateur book reviewer for a local paper is beginning to suffer, and her only relative has just passed away after succumbing to what might possibly be hereditary madness. And as if that wasn't enough, she's begun to see and hear a smart talking ghost who has revealed himself to be something of a family heirloom.

This is The Blackwell Legacy, the first of five chapters chronicling the events of Rosa and her new life partner, Joey, who have quickly become shackled together and must now make the most of their predicament. Perhaps not an entirely original premise, but that fact seems to be entirely lost on Blackwell, which disregards any accusations of being cliched in order to tell an expertly penned and even more impressively acted narrative that quite frankly transcends the game it's attached to. Characters are written and voiced with a deeply personal feel, easily engrossing you in their lives and making you care about their outcomes despite the game lasting little more than a few hours. The plot is slow to unfold, but as the first game in the Blackwell series it acts almost more like a prologue, spending most of the time introducing you to the characters that you'll be seeing for the next four games, and in that regards is entirely successful.

It's a tad disappointing then that the actual adventure game elements so often fall into the same issues that have plagued the genre since its inception. Most annoying is how often you are left without any direction or indication of where you are supposed to go, what you need to say, or who you should be interacting with. This left me consistently walking in circles as I tried every option I could, only to realize I'd missed something a ways back that seemed entirely unrelated. It's tedious and confusing, and really got in the way of the best part of Blackwell, which is its story.

Even so, it's worth pushing through the convoluted puzzle logic in order to experience the surprisingly excellent narrative, which not only delivers a highly intriguing story in its own right but sets up so much potential for what is to come of the series. I wasn't sure quite what I was getting into when I decided to checkout The Blackwell Legacy, but am certainly glad I did and am eager to see where it might go next!

I'm having difficulties allowing myself to give this a negative review, as I definitely love the story so far, but the first game is definitely not that encouraging.

The first game leaves a lot to be desired, having numerous questions unanswered and apart from some insanely frustrating and nonsensical puzzles that could possibly even leave you stumped for hours, it's fairly short. It definitely relies on having a sequel rather than standing on it's own very well. It hardly feels like little more than a quick prologue to the games that follow it. It's good that the games are being sold in a bundle.

Even with how short it is, I definitely love the characters, story, and the humor. But the puzzles in the first game are so horrendous that I have to give it a thumbs down. I'm just going to list out the three I couldn't have figured out without aimlessly screwing around forever. At least the following game has you use some logic, rather than being a festival of trial and error.

SPOILERS BELOW

1. Talking to your neighbor
I ask you, how is this so hard? Firstly, it's insane you have to go through this in the first place. Secondly, she's your frigging neighbor. Wave at her, say hi, anything. I know you're not a social butterfly, but it doesn't take much to catch a person's attention if they happen to know your face anyway. Also you are being blocked out of your own home. Either way, the last thing I'd think to do is circle around a lamp post to get her dog's leash caught, just so it would bark at me and catch her attention. Also why does she cut the leash to get her dog loose?

2. Steal the damned notebook
Ok, stealing from the dead, nice. How does 'metal face' over there keep us from taking it when she isn't even looking at us the entire time? Oh, and I can pretend to use her phone so you can talk to Joey? That's a clever and sensible solution, I give props for that. Now why the hell can Joey not think of a way to distract her on his own? I have to tell him to do the one thing that he can physically do, which I can only know about if I exhaust all his dialogue options at the apartment before hand. I guess spending years hanging over a comatose madwoman can turn you into a really forgetful schmuck.

3. Take the dog for a walk
What? Just politely ask to take the dog for a walk. Why does everything involving your neighbor have to be a federal ♥♥♥♥ing issue? So not only do we have to drug her dog to make it have to pee, in order to actually get the drug we have to think to randomly revisit someone after just having spoken to them and exhausted their dialogue options. As far as I know that's the only way to get the pills from them.

END OF SPOILERS

All I can say is that The Blackwell Legacy is a very rough start to what seems to be an otherwise good series. Unbound is pretty good and I'm certainly hopeful for the rest of the series as I continue to play through it. I would recommend playing the first as it's necessary to play the beginning of any series you're getting into, but you'll probably want to just look up the answers to some of the more crazy puzzles for this one.

If I was to describe the Blackwell Bundle ( so the first three installments of the series: Legacy, Unbound  and Convergence) I would probably say: short and sweet. Also, plain ugly, but one does not play point and clicks for stunning graphics, does he/she?  Well maybe the Daedalic titles, but that’s an entirely different story.

‘Blackwells’ should be approached mainly by those who want to experience a nice story. I’m  aware that these games probably exploit  every single cliché known to detective- ghost fiction and  can be unbearably cheesy at times, still they are presented in an interesting way, the protagonists are likable, and generally they offer more depth than initially meets the eye if you are willing to look around (or listen to the commentary).

As if to make up for the atrocious graphics, the music is plain gorgeous.  Saxophone, piano and lots of rain in the background – a typical noir mixture and it serves its purpose perfectly.

Not without a reason I initially called these games short and sweet: finishing them took me 2 hours each (and it needs to be mentioned here that I have this nasty habit of leaving games running while I proceed to do something else), which is not particularly impressive. Furthermore, ‘Blackwells’ lack typical point and click puzzles – story is driven mainly by conversations with other characters, doing the detective work, switching between the characters and occasionally using an item or two. This results in games being rather easy to figure out – which can be good or bad depending on one’s standpoint. In my opinion the Blackwell Bundle games are perfect to play to unwind after a hard day’s work (school, saving the universe or whatever … ).

It can be argued that 4.5 Euros is quite much for 2 hours of gameplay, so it is much better to get these in a Blackwell Bundle than buy them separately. To sum up: In my opinion, these games deserve a strong  7 out of 10 and I should certainly play the remaining installments of the series ( Deception and Epiphany ) in the future.

reviewText:
The Blackwell Legacy is the first game in the Blackwell adventure series. This is a point and click adventure game, with an emphasis on detective work.

In The Blackwell Legacy, you mainly control Rosa Blackwell, a newspaper writer asked to do a story on a recent suicide at the local college. Throughout the course of the first day, you learn that Rosa has a family legacy in the form of a ghost named Joey. In the course of the adventure, you control Rosa and Joey as you try to solve the mystery of the college suicide. At certain points, you can switch to controlling Joey when you need some ghostly assistance.

While Blackwell Legacy controls like a typical point and click, much progress is made through your interviews and questioning of individuals connected to the case. You have a notebook in addition to your inventory which is used to track clues. Clues can be combined in the notebook if there is a connection, and you can bring up your notebook to question individuals further. As new information is found about clues, it is added to the notebook.

The retro graphics are well done, although I am not a huge fan of the style. It doesn't take away too much from my enjoyment of the game. I would prefer well done retro graphics than bad modern artwork.

The voice actors could use some improvement. Joey is serviceable, but Rosa's actor sounds like she is completely disinterested the entire time. Hopefully she improves in later games in the series.

The Blackwell Legacy is an enjoyable, short detective adventure game. Expect the game to only last a few hours. There are the beginnings of a great adventure series here. The notebook feature in particular was fun to use when questioning witnesses. I could also see Joey as a controllable character being used in interesting ways in future games. I recommend this game, not only because it is enjoyable in itself, but also because I expect this to be the first in a great series.

Grade: B

This game is the gentle introduction to the Blackwell series of point-and-click supernatural adventures.

Unlike some other adventure games the mysteries are largely solved by gathering clues and combining pieces of information, so it's less puzzle-based and more like detective work, with a methodical process and moments of insight, which grounds the experience - yes, one of the main characters is a ghost, but the problem-solving is built on real-world logic, not magic.

Another thing I love about the series is the way the relationship between the two main characters develops and matures, and the characters get fleshed out as we learn more about them and their backstories. You can also see the art style and character design mature with each installment.

reviewText:
Short and sweet and interesting, The Blackwell Legacy is full of character and satisfying to play.  It's not exactly a throwback to better times, though the graphics surely hark back a bit to more innocent times; rather, it's a challenge made (and met) to create a small-studio game that remembers how much fun it was, on many levels, to play computer games when the field was young.

What I mean is that there used to be an instant joy in recognizing familiar things, writ small and played back on the monitor.  This game is set in a New York City that resembles the real one, with characters who are off-beat and individual without being unruly stereotypes.  This game is not realistic, of course - it's a point-and-click adventure, and there's nothing less real than these - but it is drawn from the world around us, grounded in a life that we (or at least the New Yorkers in the crowd) will recognize as real.

It will run you a couple of hours to finish, at least if you're as slow as I am, and there are only a few main puzzles - which does not mean that I didn't get stuck in one.  Still, it's a sweet experience, and if you're inclined in that direction there are two commentary tracks you can play through after you've finished the game the first time.

Every once in a while you accidentally stumble upon a game, may it be because you got it in a bundle or because you thought it looked nice. Mostly the series are good, or good enough, decent at best in other cases. However, there are rare cases where you'd actually become hooked to a series.

The first time I began playing this game I only did so because of the Steam icon. I already had the game on a bundle at some point in time, but like most games I got in indie bundles I never touched it. That was, until I was going through my Steam library, looking for a game to play. The one thing that caught my eyes though was the aforementioned game icon, which was basically an icon of Rosangela Blackwell. As the screenshots already show, it's the redhead woman who wears glasses, two of my favorite things when it comes to women. But, okay, it did pique my interest a bit, would it manage to keep me interested?

The story begins when Rosangela's aunt, who had been committed in a mental hospital, had passed away recently. However, Rosangela soon discovers that she's a medium when Joey, a spirit who is always bound to his medium, is now bound to Rosangela, and that her aunt's descending into madness wasn't just a coincidence. Together with Joey, Rosangela now must help spirits cross over to the other side.

The game is a classic point and click game, with a unique clue system, which basically is the same as how items are combined in most point and cick games, except now the clues are gathered through conversations. Now, while I say it is unique, it also really doesn't add a lot, although it makes the story flow better, due to the protagonist not suddenly gaining new information without you knowing where it comes from. This however does cause a bit more trial and error, and some puzzles that perhaps in hindsight sounds clever, but will cause you to get stuck for some time.

But there are also other points in the game where you'll get hopelessly stuck because you haven't triggered certain conversations yet. Most of them seem like the standard flavor conversations, ones that seemingly are only there to immerse you in the word and add no value. Now, given, the achievements do give away what you might need to do in order to advance, but it's still a pain at times.

However, most point and click games are both about the puzzles and about the story, especially the story, and on both acounts it definitely delivers. The game uses some clever puzzles to solve things, including the aforementioned clues system. There are some puzzles which require you to time things.

The story itself is good. It's not the best, but as a start of a series, it did get me hooked. It's engaging, and at times genuinely scary. The climax I found a bit underwhelming, because it kind of takes away the mysterious air the game had throughout the game.

The game has two audio commentaries, one being the regular, the other a retrospect, made five years after the game's release. There are other small things which have to be unlocked by entering a code.

The Blackwell Legacy is a great game for point and click adventure gamers and those who are really into engaging stories. While it has its flaws and bugs, there's nothing really game-breaking present. If you're looking for an old-school adventure game, this is the one to have.

I grew up on adventure games. From King's Quest I, all the way through Sierra and LucasArts heydays, right through to today with Broken Age and Telltale's Walking Dead, I've enjoyed the adventure game genre more than any other.

Which is why I confidently say that the Blackwell games are some of my favourite adventure games. It features a great cast of well-defined characters - including a great female lead. The puzzles are clever, sometimes challenging, but rarely impossible. The series also showcases some of the best voice acting in an adventure game - or video games at all. One would assume the worst from an indie game, but developer Wadjet Eye games brings out their A game for the voice talent.

And it all starts here, with Legacy, all culminating to the fifth and final chapter, Blackwell Ephiphany. You're doing yourself a disservice by being a fan of adventure games and not playing these. Even better, each game includes some fun achievements, as well as commentary by the funny and humble Dave Gilbert. He shares some great antecdotes on developement and admits to his faults throughout the series.

This was the designer's first attempt at a commercial game (he says so on the included commentaries) and it shows to a certain extent. One thing that annoys me with this type of game is when you can see how to do something but you can't do it. Not fully exploring dialogue options or combining clues (one of the game's cool but sometimes frustrating features) can mean you can't complete a puzzle. When you finally do, the frustration you feel at not having been able to do it before is sometimes greater than the satisfaction of having done it.

The game is only short, couple of hours maybe, but there is a level of replayability due to the commentary options. There are two commentaries available, although they really should be used for a second playthrough as they contain some minor spoilers. The game's creator speaks at length about things he wishes he could have done differently amongst others. His own admittance of things he could have done better make me feel strangely less annoyed by them and definitely earn himself and the game an extra point.

Though only short, the game is recommended for P&C lovers and achievement ♥♥♥♥♥s (they can all be done relatively easily and quickly) otherwise maybe I would say try something else.

reviewText:
Probably the shortest way to describe the Blackwell series is to call it the point & click adventure game equivalent of the TV show ‘Ghost Whisperer’, after all, the premise is quite similar: the female protagonist is able to speak with the dead and she uses this gift to help the deceased find peace and move to the afterlife.

The game itself is a classic adventure game, really reminds me of those indie titles which tried to cash in on the success of the Sierra adventure games decades ago. The writing is shoddy sometimes, the dialogues don’t really feel natural, the puzzles are a bit far-fetched, so overall it’s not a “professional” game.
But what it lacks in sheer professionalism it makes up in passion. You can see that the game was designed and created with love, and the main idea behind the plot is very sound.

Overall this is a quite short (even for a Blackwell game) start of a nice little series, the foundation on what later games built upon. Probably not the best hook to reel new gamers in but believe me, it will be worth it.

reviewText:
It was only recently that I discovered the Blackwell Series tucked into an indie adventure bundle on steam, and let me tell you, I am very glad that I
decided to pick it up. Now, let me preface this review by telling you that I'm a huge fan of adventure games. The stories, puzzles, and careful attention
to detail are appealing to me. Don't let my bias turn you away, though. If you have even the slightest interest in point and clicks, you should absolutely
give this game a go.

The Blackwell Legacy, from wadjet eye games, was initially released in 2006, but this is a re-release from 2011 with the most obvious update being a change in voiceover for the
main character. It's the first in what is currently a four game series and is absolutely essential to the entire experience, so don't just skip to the later games without
playing through this one at least once. It features Rosangela Blackwell as the protaganist, a reclusive woman working as a writer for the local newspaper who, as the
title of the game may suggest, acquires a ghost sidekick as a family heirloom.

Now, the first thing you'll notice when you start the game is the seemingly oldschool graphics. This was never too much of a problem for me, but then again I'm not too
picky about visuals when it comes to video games. Even with the pixellated display, it was very obvious how much care was given to the artistic direction.

The second thing that I noticed was the fully voice acted script. While it's often taken for granted these days, it's nice to see an indie adventure game, which is text heavy
as a genre, going to such lengths. That doesn't mean that it's without issues, though. The re-release of The Blackwell Legacy fixes a few of the voice over problems,
primarily including the voice actress for Rosangela from the later games, but her well spoken lines are a stark contrast to the much lower quality of the rest of the cast.
That's not to say that the actors were bad, but that the hardware was not up to snuff. Many times I was annoyed by hearing breathing into the microphone. A pop filter is
just a few bucks, there's no excuse.

The gameplay in The Blackwell Legacy is what you would expect from any adventure game. You have an inventory, walk and interact with objects by clicking around the screen,
and solve puzzles to progress the plot. The most unique feature is a clue combining system where you click two items in your notebook to link them together, often giving you
a new clue.

Most importantly, the story is great. It deals with very serious issues, including spirits, the afterlife, and suicide. There is still an element of humor injected
into the experience, but none of it pulls you away from the world it has built for you.

The biggest disappointment you'll face while playing The Blackwell Legacy is the length of the game. During my first playthrough without any guides or hints took me
only two and a half hours. With such a short playtime, and relatively low replayability since it has a linear story that doesn't branch, you'd expect the game to at least
sell cheap. Thankfully, it does.

The Blackwell Legacy is far from perfect, but it was an experience I'm not likely to soon forget. It's awesome story and well developed characters for such a short game
make this one worthy of a 7.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
This is a 2-3hr point and click adventure, the first in a short episodic series.  As such there's not too much to say about it.  The game is broken down into a few scenes and a few small locations, so the amount of content is limited.

Setting wise, the story doesn't really appeal much to me.  I'm just not a ghost-story person, so there isn't much draw there, and the topics covered are also kind of uninteresting too.  The voice acting is passable though, and there isn't any GUI frustration.

I have a few complaints about the game, though.  One puzzle involves completing an interaction with an NPC where at the end you automatically leave the area.  The first step in solving the next puzzle requires returning to that NPC to acquire an item from her you, and you have no logical reason to believe she would have an item you would need much less what that item would be.  There is NO volume slider in the game, and with the audio set to 1/100 in windows the music was booming loud in a few places.  Some puzzles require you to combine topics in your notepad, and you can only do so at certain times and on top of that only do so a few times in the game.  Its not really fun in adventure games when the player has to bruteforce his way through a puzzle by throwing every action at every target, and its kind of dumb here where the NPC wont respond to being asked about A or B, and only to A+B.  I as the player make the mental leap easily, but it doesn't straightforwardly apply in the game.

$5 is a reasonable price point but I can't really reccomend this game on its own, as it doesn't offer much and has a few nagging annoyances.  It might be worth it as an intro for the rest of the series but I could also just see it being skippable since it just introduces the premise and I'm sure that will be summarized in the later games.  I will find out as I continue the series I suppose.

EDIT: Having played the full series, I would very much recommend it as a whole.  This first game is a bit rough, but the full package is worth it.

reviewText:
The Blackwell series is one of the best point and click games/series I've ever played. The puzzles are solid and require genuine thought and problem solving. In almost every case, I found the solutions satisfying and got a real sense of accomplishment from working through them.

The story is just as good as the mechanics. You and your ghost companion have to solve murders and other supernatural puzzles, and help the spirits involved move on. It is a pretty unique story idea, and works very well for a point and click game because you can go back and forth between your human character (who can interact with objects and talk to people) and your ghost character (who can walk through doors and walls, but can't really interact with anything).

Not only are the individual stories in each game good, as the series moves on, and as you work through each episode a bigger story starts to emerge. There is always a sense that the story is progressing, both in terms of the individual case you are working on, and also in the broader context.

I wish all point and clicks would take a lesson from the mechanics, story, pacing, and all the other great things about the Blackwell series.

The only negative thing I have to say is that the individual episodes of the series can be quite short in some cases. Think of this as an episodic game rather than a standalone one.

reviewText:
The Blackwell Legacy is a point-and-click (P&C) adventure game which replicates the vibe of the classic era of adventure games from the ‘90s thanks to its visual style and mechanics, along with an interesting concept to kickstart the story. However, on its own, it fails to be impressive enough due to being no more than a introductory chapter of the saga, as well as a mere “demo” showcasing the developer’s skills  in using the AGS engine back when this game was released.

Undoubtedly, the strongest aspect of this game is its story. You follow Rosa Blackwell, the protagonist whose only relative eventually dies after years in coma, thus changing her life forever the moment a ghost from the 1930s, Joey Mallone, suddenly shows up in her life. This is where Rosa discovers that Joey was bounded to her family legacy (the title is now self-explanatory) for decades and that his job is to help ghosts or spirits (maybe souls?) who got stuck in some sort of a limbo on Earth after their death to move on to the afterlife. As a result, Joey becomes Rosa’s spirit guide much like her relative and ultimately start working together to solve a recent murder case involving three students, all suspected to have their spirits stuck in a limbo. At this point, the concept sounds similar to Ghost Whisperer, but it is indeed very captivating only as long as you do not set your expectations too high since it will definitely not blow you straight away. Absolutely not in this particular game.

Playing Blackwell Legacy is a lot more about the story and narrative rather than solving the puzzles. Mechanically, there is absolutely nothing new to expect from this game. You talk to people, select dialogue branches and use items from the inventory (no item combinations though) to solve puzzles. That is all there is to it. There is a notepad feature that allows the player to combine clues which can help in solving the cases. This is a pretty nifty, yet simplistic, way to progress the story and perhaps about the only “new-ish” mechanic. While the game boils down to a “been there, done that” from a technical point of view, the mechanics are nonetheless competent. The only possible issue might be its compatibility with the Steam overlay because if you activate it, the game jumps into hyper-drive -- at least in my case.

The puzzles are relatively easy as long as you click every possible spot/dialogue, however some do suffer from the illogical/arbitrary syndrome which plagued other similar games in this genre, possibly to bluntly raise the difficulty in some cases. For instance, the infamous first puzzle of the game in the first few minutes is a dreadful puzzle design, something which even the developer apologised in his commentary version of the game years later.  Surprisingly enough, for this type of P&C game, there is a lot more dialogue-based puzzles than the typical item-based ones seen in other games which may or may not suit the player depending on their personal tastes.

The voice acting is hit-and-miss in some places, with Rosa and Joey perhaps having the better voice actors. Considering the scope of the project though, the overall voice acting is generally acceptable.  On a plus side, the background music is pretty good and does set the perfect atmosphere in certain scenes.

Conclusively, Blackwell Legacy is just a slightly above-the-average P&C adventure game thanks to its concept making it to stand out than other similar games, although on its own it is unimpressive due to the simple fact that it was the developer’s second commercial game, leaving a lot of room for improvements. Not only that the game is just an introductory chapter, it is also a relatively short game which should be completed in no more than two or three hours. Investing solely in the story will not disappoint because it is pretty interesting, with Rosa and Joey having an exciting chemistry, but again, it will not blow you away. Maybe because it does not have enough time to flesh out some things. Once more, on its own, I cannot recommend this game because it is essentially like paying the full price of a book and only getting the first chapter.

The final verdict is to buy the whole saga and play each game one after another instead, particularly the first three, because that is when this game (and the series) actually shines, making it one of the more memorable adventure series of its genre in recent years.

Obligatory header to the review: I focus on four primary areas whenever I review a game: gameplay, story, graphics, and sound/audio/general things that go into your earholes. Gameplay and Story get a rating scale from 1 to 10, and the AV stuff gets a rating from 1 to 5. My philosophy on this is that there are some instances in which a game may not necessarily have that much in the way of gameplay (take Amnesia for example), but the story/atmosphere/whatever it may be is reason enough to pick it up. I'm a big fan graphic adventure games from the early to mid 90's. As such, The Blackwell Legacy, being a game developed with the AGS engine, caught my attention, and, like many AGS games, gave me a somewhat nostalgic yet fresh experience.

The real meat of most AGS games would be the story, and The Blackwell Legacy's story does well to draw you in. You play the role of Rosa Blackwell, a freelance writer living in New York, whose aunt recently died. Her aunt's death impacts her far more than she initially imagined, and it basically leads her to investigate other cases that have occurred in the area. There's far more to the story than that, but I don't wish to spoil too much. It's essentially a mystery story with supernatural elements to it. The game does quite well to flesh out a bit about Rosa, her backstory, and those of some of her friends and family. The game did try to do a huge info-dump of backstory near the very beginning, which was quite tedious, as even the game's designer admits, but beyond that, the game paces itself okay. It's the first part of an episodic series, so it obviously feels you wanting more in the end, but as a first episode, it does it jobs of grabbing you into the series.

The gameplay is standard fare for most point-and-click adventure games, where you click on areas to move your characters, and click on items and people to interact with. As such, there's not really much to talk about. Unlike most adventure games, though, you don't really spend all your time using inventory items with objects/puzzles/people you see throughout the game,. Instead, you will collect information about people and events that occur through the game, and try to combine such information to help Rosa understand them to help progress the game. It's was a bit different, and while minor, was a good touch to differentiate it from many other adventure games, like the old Sierra ones.

AGS games never really look technologically impressive in today's age; the graphics are pretty reminiscent of early to mid 90's adventure games, like King's Quest VI or Gabriel Knight. That is not to say the art is bad, though, as the artist of the game does really well to depict various places in New York quite well, like Washington Square Park. I haven't really been to much of New York in the past, but I've read elsewhere that the game does a good job of accurately depicting some of the areas there, which is cool.

The music was quite nice in some areas of the game. In particular, I really enjoyed the music at Washington Square Park, as it's rather calming, and compliments the park scenery very well. The voice acting was okay, for the most part, but I felt some characters lacked emotion in delivering their lines. The game's designer even commented that he felt some of the spoken lines didn't seem to convey the messages he was trying to send. Still, the voice acting wasn't horrible, so it doesn't really detract from the game, too much.

Some of the cons about the game include the inability to delete or overwrite saves in-game. I was surprised to see that I created 3 saves of the same name when I played, as I had thought I simply overwrote an old save. You can simply delete the save files from the actual save directory on your computer, but it's just less convenient. Also, at times, the wrong voice-overs would pop up for certain lines in the game, which was kind of strange.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend trying this game out if you are a fan of graphic adventure games.

The Blackwell Legacy was a flawed but very enjoyable point and click adventure.

First off, the flaws:

It's definitely short, like many of Wadjeteye's games, but the plus side to this is that it's an accessible adventure with a plotline that can be finished for people who may not necessarily have the time or attention span to commit to a longer game.

The protagonist takes a bit of time to warm up to--in the first part of the game, she's not particularly likeable, and seems to be overly rude for no reason. This mostly changes after the first major plot reveal in the game, where Joey is introduced.

For the most part, the story was paced well. However, the game is split into two days that function like acts--the first day is primarily exposition. It's interesting and important, but it felt like the game took a little bit too much time to get to the supernatural focus of the plot. The first sequence where you are required to figure out how to get into your own apartment felt unnecessary and unconnected to the rest of the story.

The central focus of this game is advancing the plot and moving the character development forward. The puzzles don't come in a great variety--mostly just speaking to characters and piecing together clues from what they tell you, and using those clues to speak to other characters who will advance the plot forward.

The gameplay of the game itself isn't going to be as varied as some of the bigger classics of the point and click genre, but once you accept this it's a pretty engaging story with some enjoyable characters and charming dialogue. Joey, a ghost who hasn't been able to exchange his 1940's trench coat or his slang for something more modern, steals the show with his one-liners and provides a good relief from the otherwise serious plot. The plot is cliche'd--not venturing away from the familiar folklore of confused ghosts needing guidance to the next realm--but the game is self-aware of this and manages to make it interesting enough to be invested in the outcome anyway.

As far as representation goes, I appreciate Wadgeteye's decision to feature a female protagonist who moves beyond the damsel in distress/sexy action hero binary. While her standoffish attitude seems a bit unrealistic and unnecessary and her character is a little bit flat, Rosangela's character contains elements that give her more substance than most women in video games--she struggles with anxiety and stress, and is frequently socially awkward. I look forward to playing more games in order to see her character develop further. Representation of different ethnicities is present in the game, but is somewhat of a mixed bag. There is a supporting character who is an elderly Indian woman named Nishanti Sharma. For the most part, her portrayal avoids the typical lazy stereotypes about Indian women. She lives alone with her dog, cares sincerely about her neighbors, and defends people against gossip rather than partaking in it. On the other hand, the background music for her apartment is a loop track of drum and sitar music intended to sound Indian. This is the only location in the game where this music plays, so it has the effect of reminding the player that Sharma's ethnic background is different and less normative than the protagonist's.

Overall I'd give the game a 3.5/5. The story, while cliched, was told well enough to make me want to finish the game. Joey has some pretty quotable lines that make a playthrough worthwhile, and it's nice to see a game where women have backstories and personalities, rather than just being part of the scenery or simply existing to move the plot forward.

I'm a big fan graphic adventure games from the early to mid 90's. As such, The Blackwell Legacy, being a game developed with the AGS engine, caught my attention, and, like many AGS games, gave me a somewhat nostalgic yet fresh experience.

The real meat of most AGS games would be the story, and The Blackwell Legacy's story does well to draw you in. You play the role of Rosa Blackwell, a freelance writer living in New York, whose aunt recently died. Her aunt's death impacts her far more than she initially imagined, and it basically leads her to investigate other cases that have occurred in the area. There's far more to the story than that, but I don't wish to spoil too much. It's essentially a mystery story with supernatural elements to it. The game does quite well to flesh out a bit about Rosa, her backstory, and those of some of her friends and family. The game did try to do a huge info-dump of backstory near the very beginning, which was quite tedious, as even the game's designer admits, but beyond that, the game paces itself okay. It's the first part of an episodic series, so it obviously feels you wanting more in the end, but as a first episode, it does it jobs of grabbing you into the series.

The gameplay is standard fare for most point-and-click adventure games, where you click on areas to move your characters, and click on items and people to interact with. As such, there's not really much to talk about. Unlike most adventure games, though, you don't really spend all your time using inventory items with objects/puzzles/people you see throughout the game,. Instead, you will collect information about people and events that occur through the game, and try to combine such information to help Rosa understand them to help progress the game. It's was a bit different, and while minor, was a good touch to differentiate it from many other adventure games, like the old Sierra ones.

AGS games never really look technologically impressive in today's age; the graphics are pretty reminiscent of early to mid 90's adventure games, like King's Quest VI or Gabriel Knight. That is not to say the art is bad, though, as the artist of the game does really well to depict various places in New York quite well, like Washington Square Park. I haven't really been to much of New York in the past, but I've read elsewhere that the game does a good job of accurately depicting some of the areas there, which is cool.

The music was quite nice in some areas of the game. In particular, I really enjoyed the music at Washington Square Park, as it's rather calming, and compliments the park scenery very well. The voice acting was okay, for the most part, but I felt some characters lacked emotion in delivering their lines. The game's designer even commented that he felt some of the spoken lines didn't seem to convey the messages he was trying to send. Still, the voice acting wasn't horrible, so it doesn't really detract from the game, too much.

Some of the cons about the game include the inability to delete or overwrite saves in-game. I was surprised to see that I created 3 saves of the same name when I played, as I had thought I simply overwrote an old save. You can simply delete the save files from the actual save directory on your computer, but it's just less convenient. Also, at times, the wrong voice-overs would pop up for certain lines in the game, which was kind of strange.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend trying this game out if you are a fan of graphic adventure games.

Simple, absolutely charming point and click game with a wonderful story and endearing characters. Puzzles were clever and really require you to think outside the box in a way you may not be used to, which I appreciated.
That said, the puzzles make up only half the gameplay. The other half exists in the form of extensive dialogues with other characters to which you can respond in various ways. This mutliresponse/multiquestion gameplay is difficult to explain beyond that- it's often more complex than the basic style of dialogue tree you'd see in other point and click games, and as such would seem possibly seem trite in another game, but The Blackwell Legacy manages to immerse you on a higher level than many point and click games, again thanks to its immensely charming presentation, and for a $5 price tag (possibly much less if you grab it during a sale) it's certainly worth a try.
My only complaint would be that it's suuuuuuuper short- I was expecting it to take around ten hours and it took half as long.
Ultimately, despite its brevity and the fact that it often tends towards being more of an interactive experience than a typical game, The Blackwell Legacy proves memorable, engaging, and endearing to the point that it's almost impossible not to like, and will certainly leave you hankering to play the other games in the series.

You play this adventure with two main characters: Rosangela Blackwell and Joey Malone. Part two is kind of a prequel in which Rosangela is replaced by her Aunt Lauren Blackwell.
Rosangela and Lauren are mediums and Joey Malone is their spirit guide. Together they help the souls of dead people (ghosts) that are stuck in this world to move on. Doing so they encounter a number of persons/ghosts who play an important role in the story later on.

Joey is a ghost himself so he can reach places that Rosangela cannot, but he cannot wander off too far because he is bound to Rosangela. He also cannot touch anything so he needs Rosangela for this. This poses some interesting situations in which Joey needs to get Rosangela into locked rooms/buildings.

A very interesting game mechanic is that you have to cross-reference pieces of information. By cross-referencing the right information you will learn new things which will help you to further progress into the game. Some information you have to lookup on the internet (in game) and emails play an important role too in this game.

The Blackwell series consists of five separate parts:

1. The Blackwell Legacy
2. Blackwell Unbound
3. Blackwell Convergence
4. Blackwell Deception
5. Blackwell Epiphany

Be sure to play them in that order because it is in fact one big story divided over five parts.
